segments.text: the question that occurred to me earlier but it was not an appropriate time to ask it but I'll ask it now you mentioned that
connection with Dr. Hopkins.
He had brought, he caused you to come from one place to another, and I've forgotten now where that was.
I think maybe he pulled you down to the project at Grand Isle.
Yes.
You see, when Project 9 was set up, he was the director of the whole business.
The Grand Isle area was not the only area we had.
We had researches going on here,
at Texas Christian University, at the University of Texas, in South Carolina at one of the laboratories, at LSU.
Well, I think you mentioned that you and Dr. Hopkins had both studied under the same man at Illinois.
Were you there at the same time?
Yes.
So you had known each other as graduates?
Oh yes, I knew him up there quite well.
And so we also, he came to the Virginia Fisher's Laboratory, College of William & Mary, just a few months after I took over that research job.
So we worked together over there, you see, for a whole year.
He was working mostly in the
crustacean area.
There's shrimp, blue crabs, and that area.
I was working in the oyster research area, but we were together there also.
We've never lost touch with each other since about 19 and well back in the 20s here.
Well, I thought that's probably what the connection was, but I want to clarify that.
Other than the two big projects, 9 and 13, about which we have talked, what is some of your other significant research projects that you've been involved in?
Well, my earliest research is, I deserted the, after getting my PhD.
I had problems when I got to this college in Oklahoma, so far as the library was concerned, and I couldn't get together enough library to do research in the parasitology area.
So I shifted to the freshwater crustacea, and
Some of the best work was back there in the early days.

With the freshwater crustacea, I studied cave fauna all over the United States, and described many species of freshwater crustaceans, and the isopods, amphipods, and these groups, studied plankton and things of this sort.
This was the reason the University of Oklahoma
hired me because they knew of my work in this area.
They hired me for a completely different thing.
From what I've been doing, I started with Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.
There are two sets of people in the United States that know me.
One of them knows me from my work in the crustacean and the freshwater biology area.
The other knows me from my work in pollution.
Completely separate.
One of my students came in one day and said, Doc, I hear you're dead.
What do you mean I'm dead?
He said, well, I was at a meeting over here, and a guy from the University of Texas, and he was studying cave farming.
He said, I told this
that I was working under Dr. Mackin, and he said, oh no, Dr. Mackin is one of the old timers who worked in the first part of the century, and he's been dead a long time.
So there are two sets of people.
Now, one of the significant things that came out of it early in business

Dr. Henry Baldwin Ward was also a freshwater biologist as well as a parasitologist, and he edited the first edition of Ward and Whipple's Freshwater Biology, which is a classic, in the taxonomy of the freshwater forms in the United States.
That one came out in 1918.
It was one of my Bibles before I ever saw Henry B.
Ward.
Then, and it helped to take me to the University of Illinois.
I liked that area as well as Christology.
Later on, after Dr. Ward's death, this volume was completely revised and re-

issued somewhere in the early 60s after I was here and I authored one of the chapters in the book and the crustacean area and it is studied with my species that I've described so I'm sort of proud of that book and that volume which I helped put together because it is an aggregation of people who are the tops in their line in that freshwater biology area
In fact, I like that work just as well as I do the rest of it.
There is a peculiar phase of my work at the present time, and it grew as I developed.
much of the work that I did for the oil companies I did through their legal departments.
Sometimes it wasn't, but sometimes it was.
Sometimes lawsuits came up and I began to develop the knowledge of legal affairs.
And much of my work now
has to do with the legal aspects of oil pollution, and in some cases have been hired directly to advise attorneys in
the matter of oil pollution, what it does, what it does not do, and analyses or reports, things of this sort.
This probably shouldn't be in this main part.
It is a complete sideline.
But it's been a great advantage to me because I get to know a profession.

which is completely different, differently oriented from the scientists and academic scientists, people who have never been in the academic area at all, and they're totally engrossed in the adversary type of litigation, all of it civil litigation, of course.
This... After I retired,
This part of the thing almost took over, or did in a number of cases.
I have three cases coming up in the next two months,
I've just finished one.
Now, some of the most interesting work I have done since I retired has been in the oil spill area.
This took over with first the Torrey Canyon and then the Santa Barbara spills, and this is something I had been doing for a quarter of a century.
but nobody paid any attention.
I even wrote papers on it, published them, but nobody ever paid any attention to them because oil spills were common.
But after these two big spills, the whole nation became oil conscious and spill conscious.
So I have picked up a number of
studies, worked out a number of studies.
The chief one of these was the Chevron OS bill, where we spent more money probably than we did in Project 9.
This study is completed and there were enormous amounts of money tied up in it, 130 some odd million in suits originally.
These were all settled out of court.
They were settled, not out of court, but in favor of Shervin.
Shervin got the decisions completely in there.
I did two of these for Shervin, the big one and then there was a little one along the side that I was carrying that nobody ever heard of, but me and the rest of them.
This was a big one.
We have now, we're getting ready to publish these data.
I have a copy now in there for review.
Another big spill was the Tampa spill.
There was one in Tampa Bay and I worked for Exxon on that one and spent a good part of the year on that and trained two or three good graduate students on it.
Then the last one, which is just now being settled,
was in Maine, in Casco Bay.
This is the city of Portland.
And this one has been finished, and the report has been written, but not distributed.
This one also will be published pretty soon, I'm sure.
This one will be settled out of court.
What exactly is your role in these investigations?
Now, all of these investigations will go about it about like this.
The first part of it is simply a matter of determining what damage is done by the oil spill.
When I know what damage is done in the oil spill, then I can tell these people what I think they're liable to.
For example, in the one in Casco Bay, a great lot of oil got in the under tidal zone, and it did considerable damage.
especially in one thickly populated island, a rocky island there.
So, when we get to this point, we then give them what we think is an assessment of damage.
We, of course, always have some parcels, and it would be important.
After that, I'm usually asked to
to help develop the legal end of it, the defense there is to be.
In the case of the Shervin's bill, both Shervin's bills, and this Castle Bay's bill, there will be no court proceedings, I'm sure, because the settlement is made in the one case against Shervin.
Shervin won the case outright without going to court, without any concession.
In the other case, they did make concessions, but the federal government is going to have to take the rap through a purely coincidental avenue.
Their Coast Guard moved some buoys without giving the proper notice, and this boat hit the rocks because of the damn buoys it went through.
over a year to establish that.
I mean, the lawyers were working on it.
Finally, they did get it established.
Of course, the case collapsed at that point, but we were prepared in that case for a settlement.
We had got it down to about two or three million dollars, which I thought was reasonable for this intertidal zone damage,
which was extensive in a very highly populated area, all of which scores with very valuable property all the way around.
So it's probably your principal function then is an assessment of the damage done by this bill.
That's right.
This is the first thing we do, and we never let anything get in our way until we've made up our minds.
what that is.
Then when we get through that, we'll help them with the legal force of time, if they want it.
How do you go about assessing the damage?
Do you test the water, the content of the oil in it?
Oh, we have very complicated methods.
We measure the oil content everywhere.
We use the gas chromatographic method and untied pretty closely in this to a New Orleans firm, a biologically oriented firm.
We have an excellent chemist and all of the equipment.
So we measure the oil content everywhere that it seems reasonable to do so.
And we measure the biological communities in the intertidal zone and in the bottom plankton and everything else.
And we have methods even running into mathematical analyses which will measure the damage done.
To go into these, beyond this, would be almost impossible.
In fact, I'd be sitting here next week.
I went into all of it.
That's the gist of what we do.
You don't get into the tremendous efforts that have been made to contain the oil once it's spilled or to avoid spills and that sort of thing.
Well, I get into that a little bit.
You mean the containment of the spill.
I have some strong ideas on that, but I'm not an engineer.
This really belongs to the engineers.
and I pretty well let them have it when I can, but I do have some strong ideas on it, and I also have some real good studies on the detergents which are used in cleanup and things of this sort.
These always play a part in all of the studies.
detergents and cleanup of the spill, not cleaning the inside of the tank or something?
Well, take, for example, the Shervin spill.

When they were trying to put that fire out, that big platform caught on fire and burned for weeks, and then when they were working on the thing, trying to cap these wells, about seven or eight of them on one platform,
They use detergents to keep the oil washed off the thing because it's a fire hazard to the firefighters.
This is Red Adair's group working on it.
They use these detergents and these detergents are pretty highly toxic.
Ten times more than oil is.
Oil is only very slightly toxic.
But these detergents and some of the other chemicals that they use are highly toxic.

toxic we believe that there was actually some damage under the platform by these detergents in the case of this spill over there although we can't actually be sure of it the data do show it this is as far as we went was confined to the center field of the platform and didn't get anywhere else and so all kinds of collateral problems of this
My idea is that what they should do in a spill at sea is to use a suction dredge and sink all of that oil with silt onto the bottom.
And the reason for that is that we have never found anywhere in the world where the bottom fauna in an offshore situation has ever been damaged, no matter how much oil gets down.
We found a lot of oil from Chevron was incorporated in the mud in the bottom, but there was no damage there.
There are technical reasons for that, bearing upon the solubility of various fractions of oil and on the volatility of various fractions of oil, things of this sort.
and the toxic fractions are the ones which are most soluble and which will evaporate, like benzene, xylene, and these fractions.
They are lost into the atmosphere very rapidly.
24 hours is usually sufficient.
In other words, when the oil gets on the water,
you lose practically all of the toxic fractions.

It's only when this oil goes into the intertidal zone where it does real damage, and depending upon where you are and what you do about that intertidal zone and how you clean it up, damage may be extensive.
This was true in the Torrey Canyon spill where they used highly toxic
surfactants to clean the beach, as well as other methods of cleaning, like bulldozing and things of this sort.
So, you have to take all of these things into consideration.
All of the methods depend upon where you are, what kind of, how close to
The land, the spill is, all of these things play a part in it.
I shouldn't have got off on that, but a good part of my work recently has been on that area.
